raw_text:
Federer joins all-time greats
 
 The last year has seen one player dominate men's tennis, and one country dominate the women's game.
 
 Roger Federer became the first man since Mats Wilander in 1988 to win three Grand Slams in one season. And after Anastasia Myskina became the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam at the French Open, two more followed at Wimbledon and the US Open. Meanwhile, Briton Tim Henman enjoyed his best year, while Greg Rusedski fought back superbly from adversity. Federer began the year as world number one and holder of the Wimbledon and Masters Cup titles, and set about conquering new ground. The Swiss sounded warning of the dominance to come at the Australian Open.
 
 He ripped through the draw before beating Marat Safin in the final. Andy Roddick was the only player to put up any real resistance at Wimbledon, and Federer's performance against Lleyton Hewitt in the US Open final was breathtaking. Federer again got the better of Hewitt in the season-ending Masters Cup. His victory in Houston proved to be his 13th successive win in a final, an Open era record. The only major let-down was a third-round loss to Gustavo Kuerten at the French Open, and Roland Garros will be his main target in 2005.
 
 There was also a surprise loss to the unheralded Tomas Berdych at the Olympic Games, which saw Chile dominate as Nicoals Massu took the singles and then paired up with Fernando Gonzaelz to win doubles gold. Another major trophy that looks beyond Federer is the Davis Cup, which was won by Spain in a 3-2 home success over the USA in Seville. Roddick struggled on the clay, losing to Rafael Nadal on the opening day before going down to Carlos Moya in the all-important fourth rubber.
 
 Henman broke new ground by reaching the semis on clay at the French Open - a stunning effort - and also at the US Open. A quarter-final defeat to Mario Ancic at Wimbledon was disappointing for the limp manner of the Briton's defeat, but he remains optimistic of going further next year.
 
 British number two Rusedski endured a rollercoaster year, returning to the circuit after being cleared of a doping offence in March. With his ranking down at 168, many feared the 31-year-old's career was over, but he battled back in the second half of the season to re-enter the top 50. The Russian women finally delivered on their long-recognised promise in 2004, with Myskina, Maria Sharapova and Svetlana Kuznetsova winning Grand Slams, before taking the season-ending Fed Cup. But while the young Russians were on the way up, it was a different story for the Belgians and the Williams sisters. Only veteran Lindsay Davenport held the new wave at bay, a stunning run of form after Wimbledon taking her to number one ahead of Amelie Mauresmo, whose Grand Slam drought goes on. The year started in regulation fashion as Justine Henin-Hardenne beat compatriot Kim Clijsters at the Australian Open.
 
 A virus ruined the rest of Henin-Hardenne's year, although she was fit enough to win Olympic gold, but Clijsters had an even more miserable 2004. She suffered a serious wrist injury and then announced the end of her relationship with Lleyton Hewitt, and will be happy to see the year end. In their absence, Myskina thrashed Elena Dementieva in a historic, but woeful, all-Russian final at the French Open. Wimbledon was a more refreshing affair as Sharapova captivated SW19, showing nerves of steel as she battled past Davenport and Serena Williams to take the title.
 
 Davenport was a strong favourite for the US Open but, hampered by injury, lost to the powerful and unflappable Kuznetsova in the semis. Kuznetsova went on to give Dementieva another Grand Slam final thrashing, with the latter's wayward serve becoming one of the talking points of the year. With the Russians still improving, the likes of Henin-Hardenne, Clijsters, Davenport, Mauresmo, Venus and Serena will need to be fully fit and motivated in 2005. And it may take their compatriot Safin to challenge Federer on the men's side.
llama3.2:1b: The article discusses Roger Federer's recent dominance in tennis. He won three Grand Slams in one season for the first time since Mats Wilander, and two more followed at Wimbledon and the US Open. Federer became world number one and held the Masters Cup titles after starting the year as world number one and winner of the Wimbledon and Masters Cup titles.
llama3.2:3b: Roger Federer won three Grand Slams in one season, becoming the first man since Mats Wilander in 1988 to do so, while Anastasia Myskina became the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam at the French Open. Tim Henman had his best year and Greg Rusedski fought back from adversity. The year saw a dominant performance by Federer, with wins over Andy Roddick and Lleyton Hewitt, but losses to Tomas Berdych and Gustavo Kuerten. Spain won the Davis Cup, while the Russian women took home multiple Grand Slam titles, including Myskina, Maria Sharapova, and Svetlana Kuznetsova.
gemma2:2b: Roger Federer dominated men's tennis, winning three Grand Slams, while Anastasia Myskina became the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam.  Other notable achievements included Tim Henman breaking new ground in clay court play and Greg Rusedski returning to top 50 after overcoming doping sanctions. The Russian women excelled with wins at Grand Slams and the Fed Cup, while Lindsay Davenport maintained her position as one of the leading players, despite being challenged by a strong crop of young talents.  The year also witnessed an impressive performance from Venus Williams at Wimbledon, where she defeated Serena Williams.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Roger Federer overcame his injuries and won three Grand Slams consecutively for a third time this year, becoming one of only two players to do so. He also set new records at Wimbledon and US Open, while maintaining world number 1 ranking at the Australian Open. Federer has already reached semi-finals in major tournaments such as the French Open, US Open, and Wimbledon.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Roger Federer became the first man since Mats Wilander in 1988 to win three Grand Slams in one season, while two Russian women dominated the women's game with Grand Slam victories at French Open, Wimbledon, and US Open. Federer led the charge through dominant performances across various tournaments including the Australian Open, French Open, US Open, and Masters Cup. Rafael Nadal secured Spain's Davis Cup victory against the USA in Seville, while Henman made history by reaching semis on clay at both French Open and US Open. Rusedski, despite being docked a doping offense, saw his ranking improve significantly as he returned to the top 50. The year featured significant upsets, with Tomas Berdych's Olympic Games surprise loss and Justine Henin-Hardenne's Australian Open win followed by Clijsters' comeback from injury-plagued season. The women's game also produced historic matches between Russian players, with Dementieva losing to Kuznetsova in all-Russian finals at French Open and Wimbledon.
qwen2.5:3b: Roger Federer dominated men's tennis by winning three Grand Slams in one season, setting a new record since Mats Wilander in 1988. Women's tennis saw Russia lead with Anastasia Myskina becoming the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam and others like Maria Sharapova, Svetlana Kuznetsova also winning titles. Britons Tim Henman and Greg Rusedski had successful seasons as well. Federer is set for Roland Garros in 2005 while women's tennis continues with promising young Russians like Myskina, Sharapova, and Kuznetsova dominating the game. The year started with Justine Henin-Hardenne winning Australian Open title but was interrupted by a virus. Wimbledon witnessed Sharapova winning her title in captivating fashion, showing nerves of steel against powerful opponents. Finally, injury hampered Lindsay Davenport's US Open campaign while Myskina and Kuznetsova are also on the rise, leading to a possible challenge from Russia's Ivanisevic for Federer's dominance.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this tennis player text about Federer. The user wants a concise summary that captures the key ideas and details. They also specified that output should be plain text without any explanations or formatting. 

First, I'll read through the text carefully to identify the main points. It's about Federer's dominance in both men's and women's tennis over the past year. He became the first since Wilander to win three Grand Slams in a season. There were other notable players too, like Henman, Rusedski, Davenport, and Myskina.

I should highlight Federer's achievements: winning three Grand Slams, his best performances on both Wimbledon and the Masters, setting records, and facing challenges like losing to Kuerten at the French Open. Also, mentions of other players making significant contributions are important too.

I need to make sure I include all these key points without going into too much detail. The summary should be clear and capture what's important without getting bogged down by minor details.
</think>

Federer dominated both men's and women's tennis during the past year, winning three Grand Slams and setting records for his season. He became the first since Mats Wilander to win three Grand Slams in one season, with Henman also reaching the semis. His performances at Wimbledon and the Masters capped a successful year, while other players like Rusedski and Davenport made significant contributions. Federer's dominance is set to continue into 2005.
tinyllama:1.1b: The last year has seen one player dominate women's tennis, two countries dominate men's tennis, and three players win Grand Slam titles in different seasons. The top-ranked man was Roger Federer, who won three Grand Slams in one season, breaking the record of his fellow Swiss Michael Stich, who had won a Grand Slam at the Freenc Open. Federer began the year as world number one and went on to become the first man since Matas Wilander in 1988 to win three Grand Slam titles in one season. The Australian Open was his most successful major, with Federer defeating Marat Safin in the final. Andy Roddick struggled in his quest for a Grand Slam title and was beaten twice in the finals by Gustavo Kuerten at the Olympic Games. The Davis Cup was won by Spain, who defeated Chile 3-2 on home soil at the Seville Open. Henman made an impressive debut at the Australian Open, reaching the quarterfinals before suffering a rollercoaster year, returning to the circuit after being cleared of a doping offence in March. British number two Rusedski also enjoyed a successful year, returning to the top 50 and winning two Grand Slams, including the second half of the season. The women's tennis world saw the emergence of Belarusian tennis player Maria Sharapova, who won Grand Slam titles at both Wimbledon and the US Open. Belgian tennis player Lucie Safarova also achieved notable success in women's tennis, winning her first Grand Slam title at the French Open. The Australian Open was won by Belarusian tennis player Lidia Myszkina, who also managed to win another Grand Slam after being overtaken by Sharapova. In contrast to Federer and Roddick, Djokovic dominated men's tennis in 2004, breaking the record of his fellow Serbian Stefan Edberg for most Grand Slams won at the age of 31. The French Open was a rollercoaster for Rafael Nadal, who suffered a stunning defeat in the semifinals by Tomas Berdych but went on to win the title, beating Marcelo Melo in the final. American player Venus Williams also emerged as one of the most dominant players in tennis, winning her second Grand Slam title at Wimbledon with a thrilling victory over Serena Williams.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary highlights key aspects of the text: Federer's dominance, with three Grand Slam wins in one season; his exceptional performance at Wimbledon and US Open, as well as at the Australian Open and the Masters Cup; his performance against Anastasia Myskina and other top female tennis players. Additionally, notable wins include his victory over Marat Safin in the final at Wimbledon, Andy Roddick's defeat of Lleyton Hewitt in the US Open final, and Tomas Berdych's loss to Gustavo Kuerten at the French Open.
phi:2.7b: Roger Federer made history by winning three Grand Slam titles in one season, joining Mats Wilander as the only players to accomplish this feat since 1998. Meanwhile, Anastasia Myskina became the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam at the French Open. British tennis player Tim Henman also had his best year yet, with Greg Rusedski making a strong comeback after facing adversity. Federer began the season as world number one and held the titles of Wimbledon and Masters Cup. Other notable events in the tennis world included Chile dominating the Olympic Games with Nicoals Massu winning singles gold and Spain winning the Davis Cup. Andy Roddick faced tough competition from Rafael Nadal at the French Open, but still managed to reach the US Open final where he defeated Lleyton Hewitt. Tim Henman had a disappointing run on clay but remains optimistic for the future. British player Andy Murray also made waves by reaching the Australian Open final after winning several tournaments earlier in the season.

Briton Tim Henman had his best year, and Greg Rusedski fought back from adversity. Federer faced let-downs, such as a third-round loss to Gustavo Kuerten at the French Open, but still set an Open era record with 13 straight victories in a final during the Masters Cup. chatgpt-4o-latest: Roger Federer dominated men's tennis in 2004, winning three Grand Slams and setting an Open era record with 13 consecutive final victories, though he fell short at the French Open and Olympics. Spain won the Davis Cup, while Tim Henman and Greg Rusedski had notable seasons. In women's tennis, Russian players Anastasia Myskina, Maria Sharapova, and Svetlana Kuznetsova won Grand Slams, marking a breakthrough year, while Lindsay Davenport reclaimed the world number one ranking. Justine Henin-Hardenne and Kim Clijsters struggled with injuries, and the Williams sisters failed to dominate. With the Russians rising, established stars must regroup for 2005, while Marat Safin may be Federer's main challenger.
stablelm2:1.6b: Swiss tennis player Roger Federer has become the first man since Mats Wilander in 1984 to win three Grand Slams in a season, joining all-time greats. Federer also made history with his victories at Wimbledon and the US Open, while British players Tim Henman and Greg Rusedski had successful years. Anastasia Myskina became the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam at the French Open, followed by victories at Wimbledon and the US Open. The women's game saw several notable moments including Russian women winning three consecutive Grand Slams. Federer's dominance in men's tennis has raised questions about who will surpass him in the rankings next year.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
In 2004, Roger Federer dominated men's tennis as the first player since Mats Wilander in 1988 to win three Grand Slams in a single year. Anastasia Myskina emerged as a new force on the women's tour, becoming the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam at the French Open and adding Wimbledon and the US Open titles. Tim Henman had his best season, reaching the semi-finals at both Wimbledon and the US Open. British player Greg Rusedski overcame personal struggles, returning to the top 50 after being cleared of a doping offence. The Russian women, including Myskina, Maria Sharapova, and Svetlana Kuznetsova, also made significant strides, with all three winning Grand Slams and leading the Fed Cup team to victory.

The men's game saw a mix of success and setbacks. Federer's dominance continued, with notable wins against Andy Roddick at Wimbledon and Lleyton Hewitt in major finals. Tim Henman reached the French Open semi-finals for the first time and Greg Rusedski fought back from a doping ban to re-enter the top 50. However, Federer's main challenge in 2004 came at the French Open, where he lost to Gustavo Kuerten in the third round.

In women's tennis, Justine Henin-Hardenne and Kim Clijsters struggled with injuries and personal issues, affecting their performances. Myskina capitalized on this, winning a historic all-Russian French Open final against Elena Dementieva. Serena Williams and Venus Williams maintained their dominance, while Amelie Mauresmo continued her Grand Slam drought after finishing second at the French Open.

The year's major tournaments saw Lindsay Davenport emerge as a new top contender on the women's side, winning Olympic gold and challenging Serena Williams for US Open title. Meanwhile, Rafael Nadal, Maria Sharapova, and Fernando Gonzalez won doubles gold for Chile in the Olympics.

In conclusion, 2004 was marked by dominant performances from Federer on the men's side and the emergence of Russian players, particularly Myskina, Sharapova, and Kuznetsova, in women's tennis. Henin-Hardenne and Clijsters faced injury setbacks, while Davenport continued to challenge as a top contender on the women's tour.
reference: Andy Roddick was the only player to put up any real resistance at Wimbledon, and Federer's performance against Lleyton Hewitt in the US Open final was breathtaking.And after Anastasia Myskina became the first Russian woman to win a Grand Slam at the French Open, two more followed at Wimbledon and the US Open.Federer began the year as world number one and holder of the Wimbledon and Masters Cup titles, and set about conquering new ground.Henman broke new ground by reaching the semis on clay at the French Open - a stunning effort - and also at the US Open.Davenport was a strong favourite for the US Open but, hampered by injury, lost to the powerful and unflappable Kuznetsova in the semis.The year started in regulation fashion as Justine Henin-Hardenne beat compatriot Kim Clijsters at the Australian Open.A virus ruined the rest of Henin-Hardenne's year, although she was fit enough to win Olympic gold, but Clijsters had an even more miserable 2004.The only major let-down was a third-round loss to Gustavo Kuerten at the French Open, and Roland Garros will be his main target in 2005.Kuznetsova went on to give Dementieva another Grand Slam final thrashing, with the latter's wayward serve becoming one of the talking points of the year.In their absence, Myskina thrashed Elena Dementieva in a historic, but woeful, all-Russian final at the French Open.A quarter-final defeat to Mario Ancic at Wimbledon was disappointing for the limp manner of the Briton's defeat, but he remains optimistic of going further next year.His victory in Houston proved to be his 13th successive win in a final, an Open era record.
